t: “Take*p up a lament concerning the princes of Israel
and say: “ ‘What*pn a lioness was your mother among*ld the lions! She*ln lay down among them and*ld reared her cubs.
She*ln brought up one of her cubs, and*ld he became a strong lion. He*ln learned to tear the prey and*ld he became a man-eater.
The*ln nations heard about him, and*ld he was trapped in their pit. They*ln led him with hooks to*ld the land of Egypt.
“ ‘When*pn she saw her hope unfulfilled, her*ld expectation gone, she*ln took another of her cubs and*ld made him a strong lion.
He*ln prowled among the lions, for*ld he was now a strong lion. He*ln learned to tear the prey and*ld he became a man-eater.
He*ln broke down their strongholds and*ld devastated their towns. The*ln land and all who were in it were*ld terrified by his roaring.
Then*ln the nations came against him, those*ld from regions round about. They*ln spread their net for him, and*ld he was trapped in their pit.
With*ln hooks they pulled him into a cage and*ld brought him to the king of Babylon. They*ln put him in prison, so*ld his roar was heard no longer on*ld the mountains of Israel.
“ ‘Your*pn mother was like a vine in your vineyard planted*ld by the water; it*ln was fruitful and full of branches because*ld of abundant water.
Its*ln branches were strong, fit*ld for a ruler’s scepter. It*ln towered high above*ld the thick foliage, conspicuous*ln for its height and*ld for its many branches.
But*ln it was uprooted in fury and*ld thrown to the ground. The*ln east wind made it shrivel, it*ld was stripped of its fruit; its*ln strong branches withered and*ld fire consumed them.
Now*ln it is planted in the desert, in*ld a dry and thirsty land.
Fire*ln spread from one of its main branches and*ld consumed its fruit. No*ln strong branch is left on it fit*ld for a ruler’s scepter.’ “This*p is a lament and is to be used as a lament.”
